definitions: process of removing contaminants or impurities from a substance or system
ritual or spiritual act of becoming cleansed from sin or moral impurity
examples: Water purification systems remove harmful bacteria and chemicals from drinking water
The purification of gold requires heating it to extremely high temperatures
Many religions include purification rituals before entering sacred spaces
The monks practiced purification through fasting and meditation

definitions: person who insists on absolute adherence to traditional rules or structures especially in language or style
examples: Language purists object to using nouns as verbs in modern English
The jazz purist dismissed any fusion with rock music as corruption

definitions: member of a Protestant group in England and New England opposing ceremonial worship
person with censorious moral beliefs especially about pleasure and sexuality
examples: The Puritans sailed to America seeking religious freedom in the early 1600s
Historical Puritans wore plain clothing and rejected ornate church decorations
Modern puritans often criticize contemporary entertainment as too permissive
Her puritan upbringing made her uncomfortable at parties with alcohol

definitions: state or quality of being free from contamination or adulteration
freedom from moral fault or guilt characterized by innocence
examples: The purity of the diamond determines its value and brilliance
Scientists tested the purity of the chemical compound before the experiment
The artist's work celebrated the purity of childhood imagination
Many cultures associate white clothing with purity and virtue

definitions: color intermediate between red and blue in the visible spectrum
imperial or royal rank symbolized by purple garments or decorations
examples: The purple flowers bloomed beautifully against the green foliage
She painted her bedroom walls a deep purple shade
Roman emperors wore purple togas to signify their supreme authority
The cardinal received the purple when elevated to his position

definitions: meaning or substance of something typically a document or speech
ostensible purpose or intention especially one claimed but not necessarily true
examples: The purport of his message was clear despite the complex language
Legal scholars debated the purport of the constitutional amendment
The letter's purport was to offer help though it seemed threatening
The document's purport contradicted what witnesses had testified

definitions: reason for which something exists or is done, made, or used
determination or resolve to accomplish something despite obstacles
examples: The purpose of education extends beyond mere knowledge acquisition
Every tool in the workshop serves a specific purpose
She approached her career with renewed purpose after the setback
His sense of purpose drove him through years of difficult research

definitions: small bag used especially by women to carry money and personal items
sum of money offered as a prize in a contest or collected as a gift
examples: She rummaged through her purse looking for her car keys
The leather purse matched her shoes perfectly
The boxing match offered a purse of one million dollars
They raised a substantial purse for the retiring professor

definitions: officer on a ship responsible for accounts and passenger welfare
examples: The purser handled all financial transactions during the cruise voyage
Passengers reported their lost luggage to the ship's purser

definitions: action of pursuing or carrying out a plan, order, or course of action
examples: The committee acted in pursuance of the board's directives
In pursuance of company policy, all visitors must sign in

definitions: person or thing that is being chased or sought after
examples: The pursued criminal finally surrendered after a lengthy manhunt
As the pursued party in the lawsuit, she hired excellent attorneys

definitions: person or thing that chases or seeks to catch someone or something
examples: The pursuer gained ground as they raced through the narrow streets
Detective Martinez was known as a relentless pursuer of justice

definitions: act of following or chasing someone or something to catch or attack them
activity that one engages in as a profession, hobby, or pastime
examples: The police ended their pursuit when the suspect crossed state lines
The pursuit lasted three hours through difficult terrain
Photography became her favorite pursuit after retirement
Academic pursuits occupied most of his free time

definitions: person or business that sells or provides particular goods or services
examples: The restaurant was known as a purveyor of fine organic produce
Local purveyors supplied fresh ingredients to the hotel kitchen

definitions: range of operation, authority, control, concern, or intention
examples: Budget approval falls within the purview of the finance committee
These matters lie outside the purview of local government

definitions: act of exerting force on something to move it away
vigorous effort to achieve something or persuade someone
examples: A gentle push was enough to open the stuck door
The child gave the swing a push to start it moving
The final push to finish the project lasted all weekend
Marketing made a strong push for the new product launch

definitions: small wheeled cart typically used by street vendors to sell goods
examples: The vendor sold fresh fruit from his pushcart on the corner
Historic photographs show pushcarts lining the busy market streets

definitions: person who sells illegal drugs especially to new users
person who promotes or advocates something aggressively
examples: Police arrested several pushers in the neighborhood drug sweep
The pusher targeted vulnerable teenagers near the school
He was a pusher of radical political ideas at every meeting
The sales pusher wouldn't take no for an answer

definitions: continuous action of applying force to move something forward or away
examples: The pushing and shoving in the crowded subway was unbearable
Constant pushing eventually opened the jammed door mechanism

definitions: informal or child's word for a cat
examples: The little girl called every cat she saw a pussy
Here pussy pussy, called the old woman to her cat

definitions: informal term for a domestic cat especially a pet
person who is gentle, mild-mannered, or easy to deal with
examples: The pussycat purred contentedly on her owner's lap
Their pussycat loved to chase toy mice around the house
Despite his tough appearance, he's really a pussycat at heart
The boss acts fierce but she's a pussycat with her team

definitions: particular position or placement of something in a location
option to sell a security at a specified price within a certain time
examples: The put of the vase on the mantle was perfectly centered
Each put of the chess pieces required careful consideration
He bought a put on the stock expecting prices to fall
The put option expired worthless when markets rallied

definitions: gentle golf stroke made on the green to roll the ball into the hole
examples: Her winning putt was only three feet from the hole
He practiced his putt on the practice green before the tournament

definitions: golf club designed for making short strokes on the green
person who moves about aimlessly or engages in trivial activities
examples: His new putter improved his short game significantly
The putter had a weighted head for better ball control
Grandfather was a putter who spent hours tinkering in his garage
The garden putter enjoyed pruning roses all afternoon

definitions: act or technique of hitting a golf ball gently on the green
action of placing or positioning something in a particular location
examples: His putting improved dramatically after lessons with the pro
Putting requires steady hands and good depth perception
The putting of flowers in vases occupied the wedding planners
Careful putting of each item ensured nothing would break

definitions: soft moldable substance used to fill cracks or secure glass in window frames
examples: The glazier applied putty around the new window pane
Old putty must be removed before installing replacement glass

definitions: game or toy designed to test ingenuity or knowledge
person, thing, or situation that is difficult to understand or explain
examples: The jigsaw puzzle had over one thousand intricate pieces
Children enjoy solving puzzles that challenge their problem-solving skills
Her sudden resignation remains a puzzle to her colleagues
The puzzle of the missing funds baffled investigators

definitions: member of certain peoples of very short stature in equatorial Africa and Asia
unusually small person, animal, or thing of its kind
examples: Pygmy tribes have lived in the Congo rainforest for thousands of years
Anthropologists studied the pygmy communities with great respect
The pygmy goat was popular as a backyard pet
This pygmy version of the plant grows well indoors

definitions: tall tower-like structure used to support electrical cables or mark a route
plastic cone used to mark areas or direct traffic
examples: Electrical pylons stretched across the countryside carrying power lines
The steel pylon stood over one hundred feet tall
Orange pylons marked the construction zone on the highway
Soccer players practiced dribbling between the pylons

definitions: monumental structure with a square base and triangular sides meeting at a point
organizational structure or system arranged in hierarchical levels
examples: The Great Pyramid of Giza remains one of the world's wonders
Ancient Egyptians built pyramids as tombs for their pharaohs
The corporate pyramid placed executives at the top level
The pyramid scheme collapsed when new investors stopped joining

definitions: heap of combustible material for burning a corpse as part of a funeral ceremony
examples: The warrior's body was placed on a ceremonial pyre at sunset
Ancient funeral pyres were often built near sacred rivers

definitions: device containing combustible chemicals that produce spectacular effects of light, smoke, and sound
examples: The pyrotechnic display lit up the night sky on Independence Day
Stage pyrotechnics added drama to the rock concert performance

definitions: large nonvenomous snake that kills prey by constriction found in tropical regions
high-level programming language known for its readability and versatility
examples: The python coiled around its prey with incredible strength
Burmese pythons have become an invasive species in the Everglades
She learned Python programming to automate her data analysis tasks
Python remains popular for machine learning and web development

definitions: harsh sound made by a duck
fraudulent or ignorant pretender to medical skill
examples: The loud quack of the mallard echoed across the pond
Children imitated the quack of ducks at the park
The quack prescribed worthless remedies for serious illnesses
Investigators exposed the quack who claimed to cure cancer

definitions: dishonest practices and claims to have special knowledge and skill in medicine
examples: The FDA investigates cases of medical quackery and false cures
Nineteenth-century quackery included selling snake oil as medicine

definitions: quadrangle or courtyard especially in a college or university
one of four children born at the same birth
quadriceps muscle at the front of the thigh
examples: Students gathered on the quad to study in the spring sunshine
The university quad was surrounded by historic academic buildings
The quads required specialized care in the neonatal unit
Raising quads presented unique challenges for the parents
Athletes strengthen their quads with squats and lunges
He pulled his quad muscle during the sprint

definitions: rectangular courtyard enclosed by buildings typically in colleges
plane figure with four straight sides and four angles
examples: The medieval quadrangle featured a fountain at its center
Students crossed the quadrangle between classes
The geometry teacher drew a quadrangle on the board
Every square is a quadrangle but not every quadrangle is square

definitions: each of four quarters of a circle, sphere, or other shape
instrument for measuring altitudes in astronomy and navigation
examples: The tumor appeared in the upper right quadrant of the liver
Each quadrant of the city had its own distinct character
Sailors used the quadrant to determine their latitude at sea
The ancient quadrant helped astronomers map celestial positions

definitions: algebraic expression or equation involving the second power of an unknown quantity
examples: Students learned to solve quadratic equations using the formula
The quadratic function produced a parabolic graph

definitions: large muscle group at the front of the thigh consisting of four parts
examples: Runners often experience quadriceps soreness after hill training
The quadriceps extends the knee during walking and running

definitions: flat shape with four straight sides
examples: A rectangle is a special type of quadrilateral with four right angles
The student identified various quadrilaterals in the geometry worksheet

definitions: person affected by paralysis of all four limbs
examples: The quadriplegic athlete competed in wheelchair rugby championships
Advanced technology helps quadriplegics control computers with eye movements

definitions: quantity or number four times as great as another
examples: The company achieved a quadruple increase in profits this year
A quadruple portion of the recipe serves sixteen people

definitions: soft boggy area of land that gives way underfoot
complex or hazardous situation that is hard to escape
examples: The heavy rains turned the field into a muddy quagmire
Vehicles got stuck in the quagmire near the river
The legal dispute became a quagmire lasting several years
Military involvement turned into a political quagmire

definitions: small short-tailed game bird related to partridges
examples: Hunters pursue quail during the autumn hunting season
The California quail has a distinctive curved plume on its head

definitions: shaking or trembling of the earth's surface from underground movement
examples: The quake measured 6.5 on the Richter scale
Aftershocks followed the main quake for several days

definitions: member of the Religious Society of Friends known for pacifism and social justice
examples: Quakers played a significant role in the abolition of slavery
The local Quaker meeting house welcomes visitors to silent worship

definitions: accomplishment or quality that makes someone suitable for a position or activity
statement or assertion that limits or modifies the meaning of another statement
examples: A medical degree is the primary qualification for practicing medicine
Her qualifications included ten years of management experience
He accepted the offer with the qualification that he could work remotely
The report's conclusions came with several important qualifications

definitions: word or phrase that modifies the meaning of another word
person or team that qualifies for the next round of competition
examples: The qualifier 'usually' softened the strength of her statement
Adding qualifiers can make arguments less absolute
The qualifier advanced to the tournament's main draw
Several qualifiers performed surprisingly well in the championship

definitions: competition or process to determine who advances to the main event
examples: The qualifying rounds eliminated half of the participants
Formula One qualifying determines the starting grid positions
